1553845655_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJV.body:
afaik the btc addresses used here are pub key addresses (as opposed to pub key hashes), this means you just encrypt your message with it.

I just googled and found this
https://www.reddit.com/r/btc/comments/8dhiu2/encrypt_a_private_message_to_any_bitcoin_address/

"Encrypt a private message to any bitcoin address that has sent a transaction using this ECIES library I just published. Feedback welcome!"
https://github.com/jamoes/ecies

note: the part "that has sent a transaction" refers to the fact, that an usual address is a pub key hash, and not a pub key, to spend a transaction you have to reveal the pub key, thus allowing this protocol

1554128617_1BMRs7eu9rH13ZmjhkXfdQpfNtury.body:
I would recommend 2 things;

1. Use escrow/collateral to pay devs
(atleast until a meaningful 'smart contract' exists)

2. Just start with the work and proof that there is a market willing to pay people.
Just throwing money at things will not solve problems, and will never be able to compete with enthusiasm. Try to make enthusiasm worth it. 

I can say that I would pay for this kind of work if I would have a stable enough income/ enough wealth, but if I see no one working on it or I don't see anything worthwhile , there's no reason to form a market. 

Thus, do good work, show enthusiasm, (give a (segwit/bech32) btc address), and prove that people are willing to make it worth the time invested.

1555441653_1KKyuMCpzQ3ZxrT8tpkrBaqodWLiy.body:
well you have to think of it in cycles, first it's centralized to develop, then it spreads for adoption, then it centralizes for efficiency, then it spreads for competition, etc.

see history of bittorrent protocol and services like youtube, because of the decentralized alternatives, the centralized ones where possible, because it was really hard to stop them, while it was trivial before to stop centralized services.

See: (I heard this one recently)
https://medium.com/@simonhmorris/why-bittorrent-mattered-bittorrent-lessons-for-crypto-1-of-4-fa3c6fcef488
or in audio form;
https://anchor.fm/thecryptoconomy/episodes/CryptoQuikRead_219---Why-BitTorrent-Mattered-Lessons-for-Crypto-1-of-4-e3ghrs

1555844108_19r2tS5GqeMQnxmyPq9ufD79LXoMV.body:
The most difficult part for most people with Bitcoin is that you have financial sovereignty.
On layer 1 there are no charge backs, it is a push system. (You could add charge backs to the system, but not on the basic layer)

With how bad the current population is at digital security, this in practice results in lower security, because people use SMS as 2fa (which is a bad idea if there is profit to make from sim swapping you), store their private keys in insecure ways (largely due to lacking education), lose their private keys, and are generally not in the mindset of taking full responsibility.

In theory, the security is much higher, because if you create and store your private keys securely, you can guarantee that you, and only you have access to the bitcoin (the ability to spend the utxo), which is something very unique about bitcoin, and for me (and others) makes it a very important system for humanity as a whole.

Adding to the part of losing an amount, if you make sure to not pay to the wrong address (which with a bit of knowledge is actually hard to do) you can not lose a transferred amount, rather the "push" may not go through (see orphaned blocks). 

With lightning the system is a bit different and I could expand if you wanted to

> [muted](#comment_3_1EDaUQeKHEfXBXUFAuUwvWDSp7VZwAxN8b): Yes, some banks are actually looking to adopt blockchain to secure transactions.

2. even if it were, using a blockchain is a really bad idea

> [shitnotworking](#comment_14_14ogJNYFcw4vvWiy79raBJorUEcJHx1BEW): A blockchain is a ledger of transactions. Banks use ledgers, but they're slowAF and not up to snuff digitally (See: SWIFT, who are also developing their own Blockchain). [...]

I think you meant to @delirium
but to answer; what is useful for a central entity? a central database Ã  la MySQL that we know how to do very well and has existed for decades, or a system that is build explicitly for a decentralized nature, that in the form of blockchain apparently no one knows how to do, and the concept itself is NOT new (see Torah).

And the cost of MySql for thousands of transactions is next to nothing, cost of using blockchain is very high (note: if decentralization is not required, an append-only database with hashing gives the same properties much more efficient).

P.S. Needless to say it's stupid to claim that a bank with a ledger wants to use a database that cuts down on transaction costs (excluding most Systems, apparently) that also happens to be similar to what they already use...

> [shitnotworking](#comment_14_14ogJNYFcw4vvWiy79raBJorUEcJHx1BEW): (excluding Bitcoin, apparently)

Well, if bad research is to be believed, bitcoin is boiling the oceans, causing the next climate crisis, and so many system say they have a better solution, so which side is claiming that a blockchain is efficient (for centralized usage)?

1556212621_166W3JhPgc183GgfmPqRdKebZbPgj.body:
With free speech comes all speech, be it speech you like, or speech you don't like.

If you want a whitelisting feature I'd say pexo shows one good option, if you want more, you can make a PR.

But if you care about what people think you do while you aren't doing it (cf. common knowledge game), just because they don't understand it (and don't want to, because of cognitive dissonance), and want to put everything in a neat little box, I don't think this kind of software is necessarily for you.

I think that restricting any humans freedom, who does not take away someone else's freedom in the act (+-),  is unethical, thus there is no way to please everyone and that is the point; what one calls ethical, the other calls unethical and vice versa.

If you then say that a video of someone shooting breaks that logic, quite the opposite; the act is amoral, the video is not. The video itself is (atleast in digital form) a string of bits, a pattern of current and not current. You could redefine these patterns, and make anything into a file that would require censoring (although you could then argue the encoding and decoding holds the file itself, but that is not quite right) therefore anything should be censored. And that is the problem in censoring this kind of data.

I don't encourage the creation and distribution of these files, but that is what comes with free speech, and seeing Assange's case, I find the benefits of free speech outweigh these negatives far and wide.

Also you don't have to share files with people, if you don't like the files!

Edit: Free Speech, but without the forms of speeches you don't like is not free speech
Edit 2: The main thing with censoring is who decides what should and shouldn't be censored.
Edit 3: 
For me it's important that people have a choice. Giving the tools for whitelisting and blacklisting is good, so you can easily use and create custom filters (using RegEx and such), but forcing them not so good.
Also, if you don't associate and spend time with people that share these sorts of files, what's the big issue? somewhere somehow bad things will happen, if you can, help people to resolve issues, but simply censoring does not resolve them.
I'd say a form of web of trust would help

1556264224_14ag9EPpibuu24eZB36siFqaR4MGK.body:
I called to close a USD account after making a last transfer. (Wanted it to be closed asap)
I was told to just send a msg online and it would be done.

That happened, but even though the transfer was shown as complete, somehow it failed because of the account close shortly thereafter.

Adding to that, then my parents were called to reach me (instead of messaging me on their site), and I had to call them to say to use funds of literally any other account for closing purposes, I told the person on the other side that this could have been done online instead of per call, the person said they can't do that, but will note down that I will not be contacted per phone anymore (...), and before I could explain further, they quickly hung up on me.

Note: the bank is in EU and thankfully no negative interest yet, but I live with the mantra of "don't hold more fiat than you are willing to lose"
Also, especially seeing how other banks are doing, mine seems to be great in comparison, there isn't too much to complain about mine.

1556406701_1PTLdvcq9U4wKG1J3Gr4z1wB8LWMy.body:
I'd think implementing custom made filters that you can share would be better.

E.g.: Doing RegEx on Titles/Desciption, specific links, whitelist/blacklist, etc.  sou you can filter out what you dont want to see, instead of creating distinct zites for specific video content.

Note: If I'm seeing it correctly, most porn vids you see on the zite are the same, i.e. on the first page you always see the same ones, if I sort by 'view new' I hardly see any (atleast judging by title and thumbnail)
I'll try and fiddle around with adguard filters, I'd think that would work

So far I got that:

1. couldn't easily get rid of the elements with adguard (and ublock origin), saw that userstyles can be used directly in adguard, did some userstyles recently so used that.

2. using userstyles (i.e. stylus for me) you can hide the image and title easily with;

a[href="?watch=#vidnumber#_149EPBN4hQRpwj5TcoPETepnoXHCUXzaCN"] 
{ display: none !important; }

(with '#vidnumber#' being something like '123456')

but that does not get rid of the element, which as far as I can see I can't do per userstyles, although hiding the image and title is atleast something.

\3. using js per tampermonkey or similar should be able to get the parent element of the a[href ....] and hide it completely, but as I have never written a script there I can't get it to work yet :P

> [fantoski](#comment_6_191qyhaRxXEx1bdtG65iQvFddtXBjgo6j3): Just saw it. The fear that I had was that if we used vanitygen twice for the same keyword, it would try the same combinations and thus come up with the same result on both tries. Well if it would work in that way, that would have been a problem on release ^^

Edit: As a sidenote, as the address is a pub key hash, guessing 0, then 1, then 2 is (effectively) the same as guessing entirely random

1556845763_1AsV7xMgu5zcF66YxZFYUp1utR12M.body:
Zero/Nothing:  Nihilum, Nihil, Nil (Latin) Sunya (Sanskrit), Rei (Japanese)
' nihil obstat "nothing stands in the way" '

cipher < cifre < cifra < sifr < safara < Sunya (looking up the etymology of cipher, looks like it came from sanskrit, same with zero)

Zinc (from chemical element, Symbol Zn, i.e. identical to ZeroNet abbrev.) < Zink < Zinke < Zinko < zint < tine/tindr

Potentialy combine of some of these, then shorten

Edit:
Example of shortening I did for a game idea;
Faction that combines Halo Flood and Origami (also giving them japanese army characteristics), taking the idea and meaning of flood and origami, then looking for fitting words in japanese; 
ori - folding, kami - paper, oo - great, mizu - water
Resulting name Oorizukami shortened Orizu
